target: A form of electromagnetic radiation that is visible to the human eye and enables us to see objects.
The phenomenon of bouncing back of light into the same medium after striking a surface.
The ray of light that strikes a reflecting surface.
The ray of light that is sent back from the surface after reflection.

prompt: What is a normal in reflection/refraction?
target: An imaginary line drawn perpendicular to the reflecting or refracting surface at the point of incidence.
The angle between the incident ray and the normal.
The angle between the reflected ray and the normal.

First Law: The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection (∠i = ∠r). Second Law: The incident ray, the reflected ray, and the normal to the surface at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
A mirror with a flat reflecting surface.
An image formed when light rays actually meet after reflection or refraction; it can be obtained on a screen.
An image formed when light rays appear to meet after reflection or refraction (but do not actually meet); it cannot be obtained on a screen.
A mirror whose reflecting surface is a part of a sphere.
A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved inwards (towards the center of the sphere).
A spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved outwards.

prompt: What is the pole (P) of a spherical mirror?
target: The geometric center of the reflecting surface of the spherical mirror.

prompt: Define center of curvature (C) of a spherical mirror.
target: The center of the sphere of which the mirror's reflecting surface is a part.

prompt: What is radius of curvature (R) of a spherical mirror?
target: The distance between the pole (P) and the center of curvature (C) of the spherical mirror.

prompt: Define principal axis of a spherical mirror.
target: The straight line passing through the pole (P) and the center of curvature (C) of a spherical mirror.

prompt: What is principal focus (F) of a concave mirror?
target: A point on the principal axis where rays of light parallel to the principal axis converge after reflection.

prompt: Define principal focus (F) of a convex mirror.
target: A point on the principal axis from which rays of light parallel to the principal axis appear to diverge after reflection.

prompt: What is focal length (f) of a spherical mirror?
target: The distance between the pole (P) and the principal focus (F) of the spherical mirror. (Relationship: f = R/2)

prompt: Define aperture of a spherical mirror.
target: The diameter of the reflecting surface of the spherical mirror.

prompt: What is magnification (m) produced by a mirror?
target: The ratio of the height of the image (h') to the height of the object (h). (Also m = -v/u).
The phenomenon of bending of light when it travels obliquely from one transparent medium to another.
The angle between the refracted ray and the normal.

First Law: The incident ray, the refracted ray, and the normal to the interface of two transparent media at the point of incidence, all lie in the same plane. Second Law (Snell's Law): The ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction is constant for a given pair of media and for light of a given color (sin i / sin r = constant).

prompt: Define refractive index (n) of a medium.
target: The ratio of the speed of light in vacuum (or air) to the speed of light in that medium. (Also, a measure of the bending ability of light by the medium).
The refractive index of a medium with respect to vacuum (or air).
The refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1 (n₂₁ = n₂/n₁ = v₁/v₂).

prompt: What is an optically denser medium?
target: A medium with a higher refractive index, where the speed of light is less.
A medium with a lower refractive index, where the speed of light is more.
The perpendicular shift in the path of an incident ray of light as it emerges from a refracting medium like a glass slab.
A transparent refracting medium bounded by two spherical surfaces or one spherical and one plane surface.
A lens that is thicker at the center and thinner at the edges; it converges parallel rays of light.
A lens that is thinner at the center and thicker at the edges; it diverges parallel rays of light.

prompt: What is the optical centre (O) of a lens?
target: The central point of a lens through which a ray of light passes without any deviation.

prompt: Define principal focus (F) of a convex lens.
target: A point on the principal axis where rays of light parallel to the principal axis converge after refraction. (Lenses have two principal foci).

prompt: What is principal focus (F) of a concave lens?
target: A point on the principal axis from which rays of light parallel to the principal axis appear to diverge after refraction.

prompt: Define focal length (f) of a lens.
target: The distance between the optical centre (O) and the principal focus (F) of the lens.

prompt: What is magnification (m) produced by a lens?
target: The ratio of the height of the image (h') to the height of the object (h). (Also m = v/u).
The ability of a lens to converge or diverge a beam of light rays, defined as the reciprocal of its focal length in meters. (P = 1/f).
The SI unit of power of a lens, defined as the power of a lens whose focal length is 1 meter. (1 D = 1 m⁻¹).
The transparent, bulging front surface of the eyeball through which light enters the eye.
A dark muscular diaphragm located behind the cornea that controls the size of the pupil.
The small circular opening in the center of the iris through which light enters the eye.
A transparent, biconvex lens made of living tissue located behind the pupil, which focuses light onto the retina.
Muscles attached to the eye lens that can change its shape (and focal length).
A light-sensitive screen at the back of the eye on which the image is formed. It contains light-sensitive cells (rods and cones).
Photoreceptor cells in the retina that are sensitive to the intensity of light (dim light vision).
Photoreceptor cells in the retina that are sensitive to color and bright light.
The nerve that transmits visual information in the form of electrical signals from the retina to the brain.
The point on the retina where the optic nerve leaves the eye, which is insensitive to light.
The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length with the help of ciliary muscles to see objects clearly at varying distances.
The closest distance at which an object can be seen clearly without any strain (approx. 25 cm for a normal eye).
The farthest point up to which the eye can see objects clearly (infinity for a normal eye).
A defect of vision in which a person can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see distant objects clearly.
A defect of vision in which a person can see distant objects clearly but cannot see nearby objects clearly.
The defect of vision, usually occurring in old age, where the eye loses its power of accommodation due to weakening of ciliary muscles and reduced flexibility of the eye lens.
A defect of vision in which parts of an object appear blurred due to irregular curvature of the cornea or eye lens.
A condition in which the eye lens becomes cloudy or opaque, leading to blurred or loss of vision.
The phenomenon of splitting of white light into its constituent colors (spectrum) when it passes through a prism.

prompt: What is a spectrum of white light?
target: The band of seven colors (VIBGYOR - Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red) obtained when white light is dispersed.
The angle between the direction of the incident ray and the emergent ray when light passes through a prism.
The refraction of light by the Earth's atmosphere due to variations in air density and temperature.
The phenomenon by which a beam of light is redirected in many different directions when it interacts with particles in the medium.
The scattering of light as a light beam passes through a colloid, making the path of the light visible.
A fundamental property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field. (Unit: Coulomb, C).
The rate of flow of electric charge through a conductor. (I = Q/t; Unit: Ampere, A).
The SI unit of electric current, defined as the flow of one coulomb of charge per second.
The SI unit of electric charge, equivalent to the charge contained in approximately 6.24 × 10¹⁸ electrons.
The amount of work done in moving a unit positive charge from infinity to a point in an electric field.
The work done to move a unit positive charge from one point to another in an electric circuit. (V = W/Q; Unit: Volt, V).
The SI unit of potential difference, defined as the potential difference between two points if 1 joule of work is done to move 1 coulomb of charge from one point to another.
A continuous and closed path along which an electric current can flow.

A law stating that the electric current (I) flowing through a metallic conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference (V) across its ends, provided its temperature remains constant (V = IR).
The property of a conductor to oppose the flow of electric current through it. (Unit: Ohm, Ω).
The SI unit of electrical resistance, defined as the resistance of a conductor through which a current of 1 ampere flows when a potential difference of 1 volt is applied across its ends.
The electrical resistance of a conductor of unit length and unit cross-sectional area. (Unit: Ohm-meter, Ωm).
Materials that allow electric current to flow through them easily due to the presence of free charge carriers (e.g., metals).
Materials that do not allow electric current to flow through them easily as they have very few free charge carriers (e.g., glass, rubber, plastic).

prompt: What is series combination of resistors?
target: An arrangement in a circuit where resistors are connected end-to-end, so the same current flows through each resistor.
An arrangement in a circuit where resistors are connected between two common points, so the potential difference across each resistor is the same.

prompt: What is heating effect of electric current?
target: The phenomenon where heat is produced in a resistor when electric current flows through it.

The law stating that the heat (H) produced in a resistor is directly proportional to (i) the square of the current (I²) through it, (ii) its resistance (R), and (iii) the time (t) for which the current flows (H = I²Rt).
The rate at which electrical energy is consumed or dissipated in an electric circuit. (P = VI = I²R = V²/R; Unit: Watt, W).
The SI unit of electric power, defined as the power consumed when a current of 1 ampere flows at a potential difference of 1 volt.
The commercial unit of electrical energy, equivalent to the energy consumed by an appliance of 1 kilowatt power operating for 1 hour. (1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J).
A material or object that produces a magnetic field, attracting ferromagnetic materials like iron.
The region around a magnet or a current-carrying conductor within which its magnetic influence can be experienced.
Imaginary lines used to represent the strength and direction of a magnetic field.
The two regions of a magnet where the magnetic field strength is greatest.

prompt: State the right-hand thumb rule for a straight conductor.
target: If the conductor is held in the right hand with the thumb pointing in the direction of the current, then the fingers will curl around the conductor in the direction of the magnetic field lines.
A long coil of insulated copper wire wound in the shape of a cylinder, which produces a strong, uniform magnetic field inside it when current flows through it, similar to a bar magnet.
A temporary magnet consisting of a coil of wire wound around a soft iron core, which becomes magnetic only when an electric current flows through the coil.

If the thumb, forefinger, and middle finger of the left hand are stretched mutually perpendicular to each other such that the forefinger points in the direction of the magnetic field and the middle finger points in the direction of the current, then the thumb will point in the direction of the force or motion.
A device that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.
The rotating coil of wire in an electric motor or generator.
A device used in DC motors and DC generators to reverse the direction of current in the armature coil.

The phenomenon of producing an induced electromotive force (and hence current, if the circuit is closed) in a conductor when it is moved through a magnetic field or when the magnetic field around it changes.
The electric current produced in a conductor due to electromagnetic induction.

If the thumb, forefinger, and middle finger of the right hand are stretched mutually perpendicular to each other such that the thumb points in the direction of motion of the conductor and the forefinger points in the direction of the magnetic field, then the middle finger will point in the direction of the induced current.
A device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy using the principle of electromagnetic induction.
An electric current that reverses its direction periodically.
An electric current that flows in only one direction.
The number of cycles of alternating current completed in one second. (Unit: Hertz, Hz).
A safety device consisting of a wire with a low melting point that melts and breaks an electric circuit if the current exceeds a safe value.
A condition in an electric circuit where the live wire comes into direct contact with the neutral wire, resulting in a very low resistance path and a very high current.
A condition in an electric circuit where too many appliances are connected to a single socket, drawing a current that exceeds the safe limit of the circuit wiring.

The process of connecting the metal casing of an electrical appliance to the earth wire, which provides a low-resistance path for current to flow to the earth in case of a fault, preventing electric shock.
